choices.text: Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 minutes
Inability to approximate the abdominal incision

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Option A (Serum lactate >5 mmol/L): Correct. Elevated serum lactate (>5 mmol/L) is a physiological indication for damage control surgery. This reflects tissue hypoxia and metabolic acidosis, signaling a decline in physiological reserve.

Option B (Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 minutes): Correct. Persistent hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg for >60 minutes) is an indication for damage control surgery, as it suggests inadequate perfusion and shock.

Option C (Ability to achieve hemostasis): Incorrect. The inability to achieve hemostasis is a key anatomical indication for damage control surgery. If hemostasis cannot be achieved, damage control surgery is considered to temporarily control the situation.

Option D (Inability to approximate the abdominal incision): Correct. If the abdominal incision cannot be approximated, it suggests excessive abdominal contents or swelling that requires damage control surgery to temporarily close the abdomen and reassess later.

Indications for Damage Control Surgery

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34°C
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

Key Points:

  • Damage Control Surgery is indicated when there is either:
  • Anatomical factors (e.g., inability to control bleeding, complex injuries)
  • Physiological factors (e.g., metabolic acidosis, severe hypotension)
  • Environmental factors (e.g., prolonged operating time, difficulty in closing the abdomen)

Tags:

Topic: Damage Control Surgery

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-29, page no. -386

questions.text: Which of the following hemoglobin levels would most likely benefit from a blood transfusion before surgery?
questions.solution:
Option A (<6 g/dL): Correct. Hemoglobin levels below 6 g/dL are typically considered severe anemia, and patients are likely to benefit from a blood transfusion due to the potential for inadequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

Option B (6-8 g/dL): Incorrect. Blood transfusion is usually only indicated for this range if the patient has ongoing blood loss or is about to undergo surgery, as the body may tolerate these levels without immediate intervention in the absence of other risk factors.

Option C (>8 g/dL): Incorrect. Transfusions are generally not indicated when the hemoglobin level is above 8 g/dL, unless there are specific risk factors or the patient is symptomatic.

Option D (None of the above): Incorrect. Hemoglobin levels below 6 g/dL typically warrant a transfusion in most clinical settings.

Key Points:

<6 g/dL: Blood transfusion is almost always beneficial.

6-8 g/dL: Blood transfusion is considered based on clinical context (e.g., ongoing blood loss, surgery).

>8 g/dL: Generally does not require transfusion unless there are other risk factors.

Tags:

Topic: Anemia Management

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 21, page no. -292

choices.text: Unintentional weight loss >15% in the last 3-6 months
Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days
BMI <18.5 kg/m² with adequate nutritional intake in the last 3 days

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for developing refeeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A (BMI <16 kg/m²): Correct. A BMI less than 16 kg/m² is a major risk factor for refeeding syndrome, as it indicates severe malnutrition.

Option B (Unintentional weight loss >15% in the last 3-6 months): Correct. This level of weight loss is a significant indicator of malnutrition and a risk factor for refeeding syndrome.

Option C (Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days): Correct. A prolonged lack of nutritional intake for more than 10 days increases the risk of refeeding syndrome when nutrition is reintroduced.

Option D (BMI < 18.5 kg/m² with adequate nutritional intake in the last 3 days): Incorrect. Although a BMI less than 18.5 kg/m² is a risk factor, if the patient has had adequate nutritional intake in the past 3 days, this significantly reduces the likelihood of refeeding syndrome.

  • Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal condition that occurs when nutrition is reintroduced to a malnourished or starved individual. It is characterized by shifts in fluids and electrolytes, particularly a rapid decrease in serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels, as the body transitions from a catabolic to an anabolic state. This metabolic disturbance can lead to complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, muscle weakness, and neurological symptoms.
  • Patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER:
  • One or more of the following:
    • BMI <16 kg/m²
    • Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months
    • Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days
    • Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding

OR

  • Two or more of the following:
    • BMI <18.5 kg/m²
    • Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months
    • Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days
    • History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics
  • Management:
    • Gradual reintroduction of calories, particularly carbohydrates, to avoid sudden metabolic shifts.
    • Monitoring and correction of electrolyte levels, especially phosphate, potassium, and magnesium, before and during nutritional repletion.
    • Close monitoring of vital signs and symptoms during the refeeding process.
    • Prevention: Screening for risk factors in malnourished patients and initiating refeeding cautiously can help prevent refeeding syndrome.

Tags:

Topic: Refeeding Syndrome

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 25, page no. -340.

choices.text: Open the hematoma for direct control
Compression or extraperitoneal packing without exploration

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with blunt trauma to the abdomen, and a pelvic hematoma is identified on imaging. The hematoma is stable and not expanding. Based on the zone classification for abdominal trauma, what is the best approach for management of this pelvic hematoma?
questions.solution:
Option A (Immediate exploration of the hematoma): Incorrect. Pelvic hematomas should not be explored immediately unless they are expanding or pulsatile, or if there is evidence of a penetrating injury. This is usually reserved for more severe cases.

Option B (Angioembolization only if bleeding is arterial): Correct. If the pelvic hematoma is identified as originating from an arterial source and is unstable or expanding, angioembolization is the preferred method of control.

Option C (Open the hematoma for direct control): Incorrect. Pelvic hematomas are exceptionally difficult to control surgically and should not be opened unless absolutely necessary, particularly in the absence of expanding or pulsatile bleeding.

Option D (Compression or extraperitoneal packing without exploration): Correct. In stable pelvic hematomas, non-invasive methods like compression or extraperitoneal packing should be attempted first. These methods help control the bleeding without the need for direct exploration, which can be challenging in the pelvic region.

Key Points:

Zone 1 (central): Hematomas in the central zone should always be explored once vascular control is obtained.

Zone 2 (lateral): Hematomas in this area should only be explored if expanding, pulsatile, or if penetrating injury is present.

Zone 3 (pelvic): Pelvic hematomas should generally not be opened unless necessary; they are best managed with compression or extraperitoneal packing, or angioembolization in cases of arterial bleeding.

Tags:

Topic: Trauma, Abdominal and Pelvic Injury

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -29, Page -383

choices.text: Clamping of the chest tube to tamponade bleeding
Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) with low-pressure suction
Administration of intravenous antibiotics and waiting for drainage to resolve

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents following blunt chest trauma. He is in hemorrhagic shock, with flat neck veins and absent breath sounds on the affected side. A chest radiograph reveals a large pleural effusion. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A (Immediate thoracotomy): Incorrect. Immediate thoracotomy is indicated if more than 1500 mL of blood is initially drained or if ongoing bleeding exceeds 200 mL/h for 3-4 hours. This patient requires an intercostal drain first, with surgery being considered if the situation does not improve.

Option B (Clamping of the chest tube to tamponade bleeding): Incorrect. There is no role for clamping the chest tube in a massive haemothorax, as this could worsen the condition by tamponading the bleeding inside the pleural space, preventing its removal.

Option C (Insertion of an intercostal drain with low-pressure suction): Correct. The initial management involves inserting an intercostal drain (ICD) to evacuate the blood. If the lung does not reinflate, a low-pressure suction (5 cm H2O) should be applied to help maintain lung expansion and facilitate drainage.

Option D (Administration of intravenous antibiotics and waiting for drainage to resolve): Incorrect. Immediate management of haemothorax includes proper drainage and addressing hypovolemic shock, not just antibiotics or waiting for the situation to resolve.

Key Points:

  • Massive haemothorax is typically caused by bleeding from intercostal vessels or internal mammary arteries following rib fractures.
  • Initial management includes the insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) to evacuate the pleural space and correct hypovolemic shock.
  • Urgent thoracotomy is required if there is significant ongoing bleeding (more than 200 mL/h for 3-4 hours) or if more than 1500 mL of blood is initially drained.

Tags:

Topic: haemothorax

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 29, Page 375.

choices.text: CBF is independent of CPP as long as ICP is within normal limits
CBF increases linearly with increases in MAP without regard to ICP
CBF is maintained at a constant rate regardless of changes in MAP or ICP
CBF depends on the difference between MAP and ICP, with normal CBF occurring when CPP is between 75-105 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the relationship between cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) and cerebral blood flow (CBF) in the context of intracranial pressure (ICP)?
questions.solution:
Option A (CBF is independent of CPP as long as ICP is within normal limits): Incorrect. While normal ICP levels support autoregulation, CBF is still dependent on the balance between MAP and ICP.

Option B (CBF increases linearly with increases in MAP without regard to ICP): Incorrect. CBF increases with MAP within the autoregulatory range, but this is limited by ICP. High ICP can impede adequate blood flow even if MAP is high.

Option C (CBF is maintained at a constant rate regardless of changes in MAP or ICP): Incorrect. While autoregulation attempts to maintain CBF within a certain range, severe changes in MAP or ICP can lead to ischemia or infarction.

Option D (CBF depends on the difference between MAP and ICP, with normal CBF occurring when CPP is between 75-105 mmHg): Correct. CPP is the key factor in determining CBF, and normal CBF occurs when CPP is within the range of 75-105 mmHg. CBF is critically reduced if CPP drops below 50 mmHg.

Key Points:

  • CPP is the difference between MAP (mean arterial pressure) and ICP (intracranial pressure), and is a key determinant of CBF.
  • Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow ensures constant perfusion across varying MAP levels, but it can be impaired in conditions such as trauma, necessitating careful management of ICP and MAP.
  • Ischemia and infarction can occur if CBF drops below 20 mL/min/100g of brain tissue, which is commonly associated with CPP <50 mmHg.

Tags:

Topic: Cerebral Blood Flow, Intracranial Pressure

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-28, page number-361

choices.text: Malposition or displacement of the feeding tube

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common complication associated with parenteral nutrition?
questions.solution:
Option A (Electrolyte disorders, including refeeding syndrome): Correct. Refeeding syndrome and electrolyte imbalances (like hypophosphatemia) are common complications in patients receiving parenteral nutrition.

Option B (Diarrhea): Correct. Diarrhea is a known complication of enteral feeding, but it can also occur in patients on parenteral nutrition, especially if it is combined with enteral feeding or due to medication side effects.

Option C (Malposition or displacement of the feeding tube): Incorrect. Malposition and displacement of the feeding tube are specific complications of enteral feeding, not parenteral nutrition. Parenteral nutrition involves intravenous administration, so tube-related complications like malposition are not applicable.

Option D (Vitamin, mineral, trace element deficiencies): Correct. Long-term use of parenteral nutrition can lead to deficiencies in essential micronutrients such as zinc, copper, selenium, and vitamins, requiring regular monitoring and supplementation.

Key Points:

  • Parenteral nutrition provides essential nutrients intravenously when oral or enteral feeding is not possible.
  • It involves risks such as electrolyte disorders, refeeding syndrome, and deficiencies in vitamins and minerals, especially during long-term use.
  • Complications like tube malposition are not associated with parenteral nutrition but are more relevant to enteral feeding.

Tags:

Topic: Parenteral Nutrition

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 25, page number. 338.

choices.text: Vital signs stable for at least 1 hour
Ability to walk and dress appropriately
Requires intravenous analgesia for pain management

questions.text: Which of the following is not a discharge criterion for a patient following day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Option A (Vital signs stable for at least 1 hour): Correct. This is a standard discharge criterion to ensure the patient's recovery is stable before discharge.

Option B (Ability to walk and dress appropriately): Correct. Ensuring the patient can walk and dress is an important indicator that they have regained sufficient function for discharge.

Option C (Has passed urine, if appropriate): Correct. This is an important criterion, particularly for surgeries involving the urinary tract, to ensure normal urinary function before discharge.

Option D (Requires intravenous analgesia for pain management): Incorrect. If a patient still requires intravenous analgesia, they are typically not ready for discharge. The patient should be able to manage their pain with oral analgesia before being discharged.

  • Discharge criteria
    • Vital signs stable for at least 1 hour
    • Correct orientation as to time, place and person if appropriate
    • Adequate pain control with supply of oral analgesia
    • Understands how to use oral analgesia supplied
    • Ability to dress and walk where appropriate
    • Minimal nausea, vomiting or dizziness
    • Has taken oral fluids
    • Minimal bleeding or wound drainage
    • Has passed urine (if appropriate)
    • Has a responsible adult to take them home
    • Written and verbal instructions given about postoperative care
    • Knows when to come back for follow-up (if appropriate)
    • Emergency contact number supplied

Key Points:

  • Day care surgery discharge criteria ensure the patient is stable and able to care for themselves at home.
  • Oral analgesia is preferred over intravenous analgesia for discharge readiness.
  • Discharge is not recommended if the patient still requires more intensive post-operative care, such as IV pain management.

Tags:

Topic: Day Care Surgery Discharge Criteria

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-22, page number. -303

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of hospital-acquired infections on post-operative days (POD) 2-3?
questions.solution:
Option A (Atelectasis): Incorrect. Atelectasis is most commonly observed on POD 1, not on POD 2-3.

Option B (Pneumonia): Incorrect. Pneumonia is a possible complication in the postoperative period, but it is not the most common cause of hospital-acquired infections in POD 2-3.

Option C (Superficial thrombophlebitis): Incorrect. While superficial thrombophlebitis is a potential complication, it is not the most common cause of hospital-acquired infections on POD 2-3.

Option D (Urinary tract infection - UTI): Correct. Urinary tract infection (UTI) is the most common cause of hospital-acquired infections on POD 2-3, typically due to catheterization or other urinary tract interventions.

Tags:

Topic: Post-Operative Complications

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-24, page no. 324

choices.text: Confirming patient identity, site, and procedure
Confirming patient site, procedure name, and time
Confirming antibiotic prophylaxis given within the last 30 minutes
Confirming instruments, sponge, and needle count

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the "Time out" during surgery?
questions.solution:
Option A (Confirming patient identity, site, and procedure): Incorrect. This step is part of the Sign in process, which occurs before induction of anaesthesia.

Option B (Confirming patient site, procedure name, and time): Correct. This is part of the Time out procedure, performed before skin incision to ensure all surgical details are correct and to prevent errors.

Option C (Confirming antibiotic prophylaxis given within the last 30 minutes): Incorrect. This is part of the Sign in process, before anaesthesia induction, and is not specific to the "Time out" step.

Option D (Confirming instruments, sponge, and needle count): Incorrect. This step is part of the Sign out process after the surgery, confirming all counts are accurate.

Key Points:

  • The Sign in is done before anaesthesia induction, confirming patient identity, surgical site, procedure, and written consent.
  • The Time out occurs just before skin incision to ensure everything is correct: patient identity, site, procedure, and timing.
  • The Sign out is performed before the patient leaves the operating room to confirm the instrument, sponge, and needle count, along with specimen labeling and blood loss.

Tags:

Topic: Surgical Safety Protocols

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-15, page no. 241.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with an increased risk of pulmonary embolism (PE) based on the Wells score?
questions.solution:
Option A (Heart rate >100 beats per minute): Correct. A heart rate greater than 100 beats per minute adds 1.5 points to the Wells score, which is a factor used to assess the likelihood of PE.

Option B (Previous stroke): Incorrect. While a previous stroke may be a risk factor for various conditions, it is not part of the Wells score for PE.

Option C (Age >60 years): Incorrect. Age >60 years is not directly factored into the Wells score for PE.

Option D (Pregnancy): Incorrect. Pregnancy is a known risk factor for venous thromboembolism but is not included in the Wells score for PE.

Key Points:

  • The Wells score is used to assess the likelihood of PE based on clinical features like DVT symptoms, heart rate, and previous history of DVT/PE.
  • A higher score indicates a greater probability of PE, with a score of 4 or more considered "PE likely".

Tags:

Topic: Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-24, page number. -324.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes a cholecystectomy and develops a postoperative complication requiring a blood transfusion. The complication is managed pharmacologically, but no surgical or endoscopic intervention is needed. According to the Clavien-Dindo classification, what is the grade of this complication?
questions.solution:
Option A (Grade I): Incorrect. Grade I complications involve deviations from the normal postoperative course that do not require pharmacological treatment or surgical, endoscopic, or radiological intervention. The complication in this case requires a blood transfusion, which falls under Grade II.

Option B (Grade II): Correct. Grade II complications require pharmacological treatment beyond what is allowed in Grade I, such as blood transfusions or total parenteral nutrition. The complication described involves pharmacological management with blood transfusion, making it a Grade II complication.

Option C (Grade IIIa): Incorrect. Grade IIIa complications require surgical, endoscopic, or radiological intervention, but not under general anesthesia. The complication described does not require such intervention.

Option D (Grade IVa): Incorrect. Grade IVa complications are life-threatening and involve single-organ dysfunction (e.g., requiring dialysis), which is not the case here.

Key Points:

  • Grade I: Mild complications requiring minor interventions such as antiemetics, analgesics, or physiotherapy.
  • Grade II: Complications requiring pharmacological treatment, including blood transfusions.
  • Grade IIIa: Requires non-invasive interventions such as endoscopic or radiological management.
  • Grade IV: Life-threatening complications, including single or multi-organ dysfunction.

Tags:

Topic: Postoperative Complications, Clavien-Dindo Classification

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 24, page number. -318

questions.text:
A 48-year-old male with a significant head injury is admitted to the emergency department. The following findings are noted during the initial neurological assessment:
Eye Opening: Opens eyes to pain
Motor Response: The patient exhibits flexion to pain with abnormal posturing, followed by extension of the arms and legs, accompanied by a stiffening of the body
Verbal Response: No verbal response due to intubation
What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A (6): Incorrect. A score of 6 would be given if the patient displayed purposeful movement, like localizing to pain. The posturing in this patient suggests abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing) followed by extension (decerebrate posturing), which is indicative of a more severe motor response.

Option B (8): Correct. The GCS score is calculated as follows:

Eye Opening (E): Opens eyes to pain = 2 points

Motor Response (M): Abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing) followed by extension (decerebrate posturing) = 2 points for flexion and 1 point for extension, totaling 3 points

Verbal Response (V): No verbal response (intubated) = 1 point The total score is 2 (Eye Opening) + 3 (Motor Response) + 1 (Verbal Response) = 8.

Option C (9): Incorrect. A score of 9 would require a slightly more appropriate response, like purposeful movement or localizing to pain. The combination of decorticate and decerebrate posturing indicates a more severe motor response.

Option D (11): Incorrect. A GCS of 11 would indicate a more responsive motor or verbal component (e.g., obeying commands or speaking in sentences), which is not seen in this patient.

GCS and Prognosis:

A GCS score of 8 or less is often indicative of a severe brain injury and requires immediate intervention. A GCS of 8 is commonly associated with poor neurological outcomes if not properly managed. Decerebrate and decorticate posturing are concerning signs of significant brain injury.

Tags:

Topic: Glasgow Coma Scale, Neurological Assessment, Severe Head Injury

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -28, page no. -363

choices.text: CT imaging within 1 hour due to more than one episode of vomiting
CT imaging within 8 hours due to a dangerous mechanism of injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident (RTA). He is alert with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 14 and reports multiple episodes of vomiting. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A (No CT imaging required): Incorrect. Vomiting after head injury is an indication for CT imaging within 1 hour.

Option B (CT imaging within 1 hour due to more than one episode of vomiting): Correct. Vomiting, especially more than once, is a key indicator for immediate CT imaging to check for intracranial injury.

Option C (CT imaging within 8 hours due to a dangerous mechanism of injury): Incorrect. Immediate CT within 1 hour is preferred due to vomiting, which requires urgent assessment.

Option D (Immediate MRI imaging): Incorrect. CT is the first-line imaging in acute head injury, especially for rapid detection of bleeding or fractures.

Tags:

Topic: Head Injury,

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -28, page no. -362

choices.text: Subdural hematoma; urgent decompression and observation

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a traumatic head injury. He briefly lost consciousness at the scene but regained consciousness and was lucid for a while. After a few hours, he complains of worsening headache and exhibits ipsilateral pupillary dilatation. On CT, a lentiform (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion is seen between the skull and the brain. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A (Subdural hematoma): Incorrect. Subdural hematomas appear as crescent-shaped lesions, not lentiform.

Option B (Extradural hematoma): Correct. Extradural hematomas present with a lens-shaped lesion on CT, usually due to arterial bleeding (commonly from the middle meningeal artery). The patient's "lucid interval" followed by neurological deterioration fits the classic presentation. Urgent surgical evacuation is necessary.

Option C (Cerebral contusion): Incorrect. Cerebral contusions show irregular brain injury, not a lens-shaped mass.

Option D (Diffuse axonal injury): Incorrect. Diffuse axonal injury does not form a mass lesion and is typically seen in high-impact trauma with widespread white matter damage.

Key Points:

  • Extradural Hematoma (EDH): Caused by arterial bleeding, often from the middle meningeal artery, with a classic lucid interval. CT shows a lentiform lesion.Management: Immediate surgical evacuation is needed for significant EDH to prevent worsening neurological deterioration.

Tags:

Topic: Traumatic Brain Injury, Extradural Hematoma

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-28, page no. 365.
